description.narrative: Create a network for learning and sharing of protocols and processes to identify solutions, experiment and generate collective intelligence.
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Quito, Ecuador Ekopark, Torre 4 Simón Bolívar S/N y Vía a Nayón

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 5 new data sources per year: 1) Maps of use and coverage of soil at the farm level to identify cattle raising sustainable practices in the Amazon as part of the global project “Data Powered Positive Deviance”, 2) Maps of citizen needs during the pandemic through the platform “Colaboratorio Ciudadano”, 3) Pre and post pandemic information about youngsters work conditions as part of the inter-agency project “Social Protection”, 4) Maps of mobility and services location in different phases of the quarantine and unconditional cash transfers, and 5) Maps of social cartography in low socio-economic neighborhoods 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year: 1) Satellite data + cadastral information and cattle vaccination registers (source): identifying famers with cattle raising sustainable practices in the Amazon as part of the global project “Data Powered Positive Deviance”, 2) Geospatial needs during the pandemic (source) crowdsourcing needs through the platform “Colaboratorio Ciudadano”, 3) Youngsters online survey (source): gathering information about changes in their work conditions due to the pandemic as part of the inter-agency project “Social Protection”, 4) Spatiotemporal data + geospatial data (source): analyzing mobility patterns during the phases of quarantine and unconditional cash transfers, 5) Youngsters social cartography (source): creating other maps based on testimonies, drawings, photographs as part of the inter-agency project “DreamLab”, and 6) QRs mailbox 2.2 (source): collecting solutions during Human Library event. 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year: 41 solutions mapped. One of the mapped solutions received the Honey Bee’s Network CRIIA Award. 1.4 6 innovation methods used: 1) Crowdsourcing- Colaboratorio Ciudadano; 2) Behavioral Insights-applied to recycling; 3) Prototype – Mozilla add-on to flag fake or suspicious job ads; 4) Participatory design/co-creation – Thinkia; 5) Positive Deviance – applied to livestock deforestation in the Amazon; 6) Pilot testing – alternative currency. 1.3 2 new sources of data per year: 1) Maps on poverty dispersion in Ecuador and CO project location as part of the Sensemaking and 2) Maps of carpool routes for UNDP officials to diminish CO2 emissions as part of the project “Greening the office”
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year: 1) Es el proceso, no la solución en sí (Jan 17 2020), 2) No todos los caminos llevan a Roma: Historia de tres recorridos en búsqueda de soluciones (Feb 5 2020), 3) El aprendizaje experimental y colaborativo a través de libros humanos (Feb 27 2020), 4) No todos los caminos llevan a Roma: Historia del tercer recorrido en búsqueda de soluciones comunitarias (Mar 23 2020), 5) Llueve sobre mojado: Algunos desafíos de jóvenes en situación de informalidad (Apr 23 2020), 6) Crowdsourcing meets the needs of vulnerable families (April 28 2020), 7) Sobrevivir en tiempos de crisis en comunidad organizada”: Historia de una Red de Costureras (Jul 11 2020), 8) Desafíos en ciberseguridad: Diálogo con mujeres internautas de la economía informal (Jul 29 2020), 9) Jóvenes en la informalidad y lo que sabemos sobre sus condiciones de trabajo: Parte 1, levantamiento de información (Agu 21 2020), 10) Otros Mapas de Nuestros Barrios: Una experiencia de cartografía social con jóvenes (Oct 31 2020), 11) Innovando a pasos (Nov 19 2020) 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart: 1) Ministry of Agriculture (public): selling fruit and vegetables baskets (i.e. Ashangas) through the “Colaboratorio Ciudadano” platform , 2) Electric Company (public): running the Human Library in house, 3) ReciVeci (NGO): using the app modifications base on an experiment on behavioral insights to collect more recyclable residuals, 4) Institute of Social Protection: starting the first phase of the behavioral insights experiment to expand the affiliation scheme to independent workers, 5) Ministry of Agriculture and Environment (public): using data at the farm level on use and coverage of soil on agriculture technical assistance programs, and 6) Datalat (NGO): using the youngsters online survey results for the school of data with youth organizations 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods: 1) Issue Mapping used by CONQUITO (public agency of economic promotion) and UNICEF, 2) Crowdfunding used by the Ministry of Environment to sell local goods from communities, and 3) Innovation Challenge used by Datalat with other actors 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: 1) Learning brought to the project of “Social Protection” based on the results of the sensing, exploring, and experimenting phases, 2) Learnings for the inter-agency project “Dream Lab” from the social cartography exercise, 3) Learning to the NDC project on how to collect recyclable residuals during the pandemic quarantine, and 4) Learning to the Ministry of Environment in two areas: how to sell communities good through crowdsourcing and how to identify sustainable cattle raising farms with remote sensing data
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network 48 interaction per year: 1) Holding active discussion by Whatsapp and Teams at the global, regional and network level (experimenters, solution mappers and explorers), 2) Running the task force on ethics, 3) Participating as speakers in the Bootcamps of the 2nd cohort, 4) Generating reflections and discussion in the frame of the Solution Mapping Course, 5) Co-organizing and facilitating the Explorers´ Summit, 6) Sharing the methodology of Horizon Scanning with the 1st and 2nd cohort in the LAC region, and 6) Participating as speakers events organized by other Labs. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related: 1) Crowdsourcing and crowdfunding: mapping needs during the pandemic “Colaboratorio Ciudadano”, 2) Using online tool to collect data from young informal workers, 3) Using social cartography to create other maps, 4) Using DPPD to find farms with sustainable practices, 5) Sharing learnings about informal work, 6) Sharing and presenting the method of Horizon Scanning, 7) Understanding data as a public good: new data management models explored 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: The Lab’s work is featured at least 2 times on CO’s social media accounts. Lab team members regularly share progress through personal social media accounts, more than once per month. Lab activities covered on local media (Human Library, newspaper El Comercio, TV program Día al Día on pilot recyclables collection scheme, TV local program in Napo on Amazon food baskets, online survey on youth labor informality on Facebook live and radio, face mask crowdfunding campaign on RadioVisión, newspaper on DreamLab project). 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: 1) Co-organization in 3 hackathons; 2) Participation in Exploralabs seminar; 3) Support and engagement with national innovation challenge Reinventa Ecuador; 4) Innovation challenge on data and youth informality with local ecosystem partners; 5) Data School with informal youngsters; 6) DreamLab engagement with UNICEF, ConQuito and Tandari; 7) Contribution to Open Data Guide dialogue; 8) Engagement with ecosystem actors from the academia, private sector and civil society to build Thinkia platform.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 10 new data sources per year 1.2 9 different type of data sources per year 1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 10 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network’s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 10 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 New data sources: Satellite data with BDPD method, surveys through social media, youth informality platform, school of data. 1. 3 Solutions: 41/35 117% cumplimiento 1 solución ganadora de HoneyBee/ 1 solución de interés de otra oficina
Output 2: 10 blogs published and reports. Over 50% of learning challenges have public sector as counterpart Thinkia Lab will be adopted by open government Actionable knowledge for informality with tools implemented, ethnography and other maps institutionalized as good practice, human library has become mainstream.
Output 3: Blog publications in social media, Ecuador´s AccLab featured in regional documentations and handbooks such as Nesta´s collective intelligence and Powered Data Positive Deviance Handbook.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 2 new sources of data per year: 1) Maps on poverty dispersion in Ecuador and CO project location as part of the Sensemaking and 2) Maps of carpool routes for UNDP officials to diminish CO2 emissions as part of the project “Greening the office” 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year: 1) UNDP Intranet (source): creating maps of poverty dispersion and project location for the sensemaking of the CO, 2) Geospatial data (source): evaluating carpool routes to diminish CO2 emissions at the office level for the project “Greening the office” and 3) Communities (source): interviewing saving associations with a financial inclusion approach in Cuenca for the inter-agency project on “Social Protection” 1.3 20 solutions mapped: 20 solutions mapped 1.4 2 innovation methods used: 1) Sensemaking of the CO portfolio and 2) Solutions mapping through field visits in three regions in Ecuador
2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year: 1) Fortaleciendo capacidades para repensar el desarrollo global desde lo local y comunitario (Nov 20 2019) 2) ¿En qué nos hallamos ahora? Un relato de la aventura de inserción (Dec 12 2019) 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart: 1) Maps on poverty dispersion in Ecuador and CO project location by the CO 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method: NA 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects: 1) Learnings shared with the Small Grants Programme based on the solution mapping exercise
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network 48 interaction per year: 1) Holding active discussion by Whatsapp and Teams at the global, regional and network level (experimenters, solution mappers and explorers), and 2) Organizing and facilitating two bootcamps for the first cohort 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related: 1) Solution Mapping methodology 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account: The Lab’s work is featured at least 2 times on CO’s social media accounts. Lab team members regularly shared progress through personal social media accounts, more than once per month, in particular sharing progress on 2 bootcamps hosted and CO sensemaking process. 3. 4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem: 1) CONQUITO (public agency of economic promotion) and 2) Reci Veci (NGO working with waste pickers)

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 10 new data sources per year 9 different type of data sources per year 50 new potential solutions per lab per year
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.

Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
